{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3207073,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-13T20:31:47.283Z","cooked":"

Hey, one of my students is working on applying LQR to the rotational component of robot pose, and he‚Äôs not sure how to address angle wrapping. Has anyone else successfully applied LQR to theta control?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-05-13T20:31:47.283Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":31,"reads":302,"readers_count":301,"score":210.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":437051,"topic_slug":"lqr-angle-wrapping","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lqr-angle-wrapping/437051/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3207079,"name":"Declan","username":"pietroglyph","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pietroglyph/{size}/149915_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-13T21:12:23.170Z","cooked":"

Your model is nonlinear, and will need to linearize.

Exactly how you linearize (e.g. around what point and how often) is important. You can also set up your model to be easier to work with‚Äîfor example, if you have a differential drivetrain and you use cross track error instead of global x and y error, then you only ever need to linearize around \theta = 0.

Sections 8.7 and 8.9 from Tyler‚Äôs book are exactly what you need for a differential drive, but should be educational for other situations as well.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-05-13T21:12:23.170Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":70.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":437051,"topic_slug":"lqr-angle-wrapping","display_username":"Declan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://file.tavsys.net/control/controls-engineering-in-frc.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29132,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lqr-angle-wrapping/437051/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3207095,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-13T22:25:24.216Z","cooked":"

thanks! I‚Äôm not sure this is a linearization issue. imagine a simple one joint arm that can turn multiple times, with an absolute encoder. I‚Äôm really just looking for code examples that work in this context.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-05-13T22:25:24.216Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":241,"readers_count":240,"score":48.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":437051,"topic_slug":"lqr-angle-wrapping","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lqr-angle-wrapping/437051/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3207107,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-13T23:07:47.022Z","cooked":"

Often, one cares about the error in angle. For something like steering on swerve, given an actual angle and a desired angle, there are two errors ‚Äì one in each direction of rotation. One of these errors will always go through 0/360, wrapping. In this case, you can always compute both errors (one will always be positive, the other always negative) and take the error with the smaller absolute value.

If the thing you are trying to control cannot go all the way around (e.g. a typical arm joint), it‚Äôs often easiest to set your coordinate system so that the wrapping point is aligned with the prohibited region for rotation. This avoids any issue with wrapping.

yeah, thanks. i think there‚Äôs also an issue with the observation itself, isn‚Äôt there? like the kalman filter correct() and predict() steps also need to be aware of the wrapping, don‚Äôt they?

Yep. The KalmanFilter class doesn‚Äôt support modifying the residual calculation, but the ExtendedKalmanFilter class does.

truher:

if you have an example of using the EKF class for this angle-wrapping scenario (e.g. in a unit test?), that would really be helpful!

We use it for the UKF tests, but not the EKF tests. The interface is similar for the EKF though.

github.com

    4.

    13.

    18.

  19.                 AngleStatistics.angleMean(2),
    20. 
          
  20.                 AngleStatistics.angleMean(0),
    21. 
          
  21.                 AngleStatistics.angleResidual(2),
    22.
